ades.doc:
This file contains a meta-description of the ADES formats, with documentation. Various .xslt files are used to convert this file into .xsd files, programs, and other things.
This meta file contains the folowing hierarchy:
XSDTypes -- describes simple, complex and group xsd types
simpletype -- simple type, with restrictions attributes: name: name of type base: name of base type children: restrict: describes a restriction name: type of restriction value: value field for restriction doc: A documentation string Example: <simpletype name="String" base="xsd:string"> <restrict name="xsd:pattern" value="[^|]*[\w-[|]][^|]*"/> <doc> String follows the ADES specification that that the pipe character is disallowed in PSV. To allow data conversion from XML, it must disallowed in XML as well. Also disallow blank elements. Therefore, all elements must match this pattern </doc> </simpletype>
becomes
<xsd:simpleType name="String"> <xsd:annotation> <xsd:documentation> String follows the ADES specification that that the pipe character is disallowed in PSV. To allow data conversion from XML, it must disallowed in XML as well. Also disallow blank elements. Therefore, all elements must match this pattern </xsd:documentation> </xsd:annotation> <xsd:restriction base="xsd:string"> <xsd:pattern value="[^|]*[\w-[|]][^|*"/> </xsd:restriction> </xsd:simpleType>
complextype -- complex type grouptype -- makes a group
Note: Not all possible complex and group types can be defined with this format -- only the simplified ones used by the ADES project. If you can't define your new type with this format, you probably don't need it anyway.
Tags and attributes used in this file.
XSDTypes -- list of types simpletype name="typeName" -- a simple type with restrictions name is usually "NameType" restriction base="basetype" -- base type restrict name="type" value="value" suxh as restrict name="xsd:pattern" value="[0-9]*" the names we use are these but anything valid would work name value xsd:pattern regular expression xsd:minInclusive limit, which may be used xsd:minExclusive limit, which may not be used xsd:maxInclusive limit, which may be used xsd:maxExclusive limit, which may not be used xsd:enumeration specific allowed value xsd:maxLenght maximum field length
doc -- documentation string like this one
complextype name="typeName" -- a complex type. name is usually "NameType" choice|sequence|all use="unbounded" -- sub-elements which may be nested The "unbounded" attribute puts maxOccurs="unbounded" on the element which is useful for sequence and choice
element|group -- elements or groups making up the choice, sequence or all elemnt. The entire xsd syntax is not available but a useful subset is.
attribute name="name" type="type" [use="requiredAttribute"] The default for attributes is optional. If an attribute is required, it must be translated as 'use="required"' which is what requiredAttribute turns into.
grouptype name="groupName" -- a group declaration name is usually just "name" choice|sequence|all use="unbounded" -- sub-elements which may be nested The "unbounded" attribute puts maxOccurs="unbounded" on the element which is useful for sequence and choice
element|group -- elements or groups making up the choice, sequence or all elemnt. The entire xsd syntax is not available but a useful subset is.
XSDElementTypes element name="name" type="NameType" [use="unbounded"|"optional"|"NoSubmitDistribRequired"|"NoSubmit" creates an element with name "name" out of type "NameType" The use attribute if it's missing -- a required element "unboudned" -- maxOccurs="unboudned" "optional" -- minOccurs="0" "NoSubmitDistribRequired" -- selects one of the above based on the xslt marks an element as "required for distribution but disallowed otherwise" "NoSubmit" -- selects one of the above based on the xslt marks an element as "optional for distribution but disallowed otherwise" element ref="rname" [use="unbounded"|"optional"|"NoSubmitDistribRequired"|"NoSubmit" creates an element with name "rname" referring to another element The use attribute is the same as above
group behaves the same as element, but ordinarily is used ref="groupTypeID" avoiding the "name" attribute variation. That's because complextypes are used for multiple elements but a group is only used as a component of some other type
--> Typical usage:
A simple restricted type RAType is used to make elements "ra" and "raStar", which then appear via ref= in other types
<simpletype name="RAType"> <restriction base="xsd:decimal"> <restrict name="xsd:minInclusive" value="0.0"/> <restrict name="xsd:maxExclusive" value="360.0"/> <restriction> <doc> RA in Degrees limited to [0.0, 360.0) <doc> <simpletype>
<element name="ra" type="RAType" doc="Observation RA in degrees"/> <element name="raStar" type="RAType" doc="RA of Star in degrees"/>
<element ref="ra" /> <element ref="raStar" /> PSVObservationFields The PSV format order and format is controlled by this block. The order is the order of the tags. The tags look like this:
where tagtype = element of enclosing element (so "optical" and "offset" may be different) name = element name. width = default element width If line-up is requiested this will be adjusted to fit. justification = "L" (left), "R" (right), "C" (center) "D" (decimal) dpos = "0" for "C", "L" or "R". For "D", it is the possion of the decimal point from the left side of the field. This allows decimal points to be aligned. This is the default value; if line-up is requested this will be adjusted to fit.
Notes on use attribute The "use" attribute determines whether a give element is required, optional or forbidden.
Valid values are: -not present- exactly one must be present 'optional' 0 or 1 must be present 'unbounded' 1 or more must be present 'NoSubmitDistribRequired' none must be present for submissions; exactly one for distributions; optional for general 'NoSubmit' none must be present for submissions; may be present for distributions; optional for general 'requiredAttribute' for attributes only; adds 'use="required"' for that attribute.
Think of this as F(orbidden), O(optional), R(equired), U(nbounded)
Then we have this table:
submit distrib general -not present- R R R 'optional' O O O 'unbounded' U U U 'NoSubmitDistribRequired' F R O 'NoSubmit' F O O
we may also need ROO (for logSNR required in new submissions FOO (optional in distrib) FUU (unbounded in distrib)
Note nothing can be F in general (just leave it out) The only way to be R in general is to be R in both submit and distrib
If you want '0 or more must be present,' such as for a list of names, use complexType construct like NameType (which is an 'unbounded' list of names) and then an element like 'collaborators' where a NameType is optional. Then 'collaborators' is one or more names.

section.name: Introduction
section.text:
This document proposes an Astrometry Data Exchange Standard for small solar system objects, e.g., asteroids, comets, and natural satellites. It is intended to be proposed for adoption by IAU Commission 20 (Position and Motion of Minor Planets, Comets and Satellites) at the IAU General Assembly to be held in August 2015. For the purpose of this document we will refer to this standard as IAU2015.
In this document we propose a definition of data types/records that will facilitate transmission and storage of astrometric data, as generated by the observers, stored by the MPC, and processed by the orbit computers. In subsequent extensions to the standard we may propose also data types/record structures to handle other data products, e.g., orbits and ephemerides.
The standard defines certain data types, which are detailed lists of information that either can or must be included in data submission, storage and exchange. These lists can be thought of either as records, such as the ones in a database, or as object classes, user defined data types, and so on. However, the standard defines the information content, not how these structures are implemented in computer codes handling the data.
The proposed standard is based on an initiative undertaken starting in mid-2014 by S. R. Chesley (JPL), D. Farnocchia (JPL), A. Milani (Univ. Pisa), and F. Spoto (SpaceDyS). The standard was discussed with invited representatives of the interested community during a workshop hosted by the MPC on May 7 and 8, 2015. The MPC workshop attendees were
\begin{itemize} \item A. B. Chamberlin (JPL) \item S. R. Chesley (JPL, IAU Comm. 20 President) \item E. Christensen (Univ. Arizona, Catalina Sky Survey) \item P. W. Chodas (JPL, NASA NEO Program Office Manager) \item L. Denneau (IfA, Univ. Hawaii, ATLAS \& Pan-STARRS) \item D. Farnocchia (JPL) \item J. L. Galache (CfA, MPC) \item T. Grav (PSI, NEO-WISE) \item M. J. Holman (CfA, MPC Interim Director) \item S. Keys (CfA, MPC) \item R. S. McMillan (Univ. Arizona, Spacewatch) \item M. Micheli (ESA ESRIN, SpaceDys) \item A. Milani (Univ. Pisa, NEODyS, IAU Comm. X.2, incoming President) \item M. Rudenko (CfA, MPC) \item G. B. Valsecchi (INAF, IAU Div. F President) \item G. Williams (CfA, MPC Assoc. Director) \end{itemize}
Following the May workshop a June 1 draft of the standard, representing a consensus among the attendees as the best path forward, was distributed to a somewhat broader group for feedback. The present draft includes additional feedback from the workshop attendees, as well as from Serge Chastel, Jon Giorgini, Bill Gray, Robert Jedicke, Mario Juric, Herbert Raab, Dave Tholen and Brian Warner.

section.name: Motivation
Requirements
Observations
section.text:
This section lists the data fields that are a part of the various modes of observation, e.g., optical, radar, etc. Observational data submitted and accepted by the MPC must be stored and preserved at the MPC and disseminated to users. Data exchange may have one of three purposes: \begin{enumerate} \item Observer submission to the MPC, \item MPC distribution to data users and \item sharing of observational data among observers and data users. \end{enumerate} In the following descriptions some fields are identified as mandatory or optional, and in some cases this depends on whether the exchange is a part of an observer submission or a part of an MPC distribution. Sharing of data among users and observers must generally comply with the observer submission requirements, although observation headers are optional in this case. When observations that have been published by the MPC are subsequently shared among users it is strongly discouraged to strip any fields from the redistributed records.
The number of digits in the provided measurements should be consistent with the stated or assumed uncertainty. As a guide, observations should be reported with roughly 1.5 significant figures (a factor $\approx$30) beyond the measurement accuracy, and uncertainties should be reported with 2-3 significant figures. Thus observations reported in \si{\degree} that have accuracies in the range 0.03-0.3 \si{\arcsecond} would reasonably be reported with six significant figures past the decimal point. Similarly, photometry with magnitude uncertainties in the range 0.1-1.0 may be reasonably reported to the nearest 0.01 mag. The MPC may reject observations reported with a gratuitous number of digits.

subsection.name: Optical Observations
subsection.text: An optical observation contains information about the astrometry and optional photometry of an image source. Optical observations are usually assembled in tracklets. A tracklet is a group of observations that are confirmed as belonging to the same object by the observer through direct inspection of the frames (e.g., in a blinking sequence), or by a software package (e.g., via great circle fit). A tracklet is typically a set of 3 to 5 ground-based observations of a moving object over a time span of up to a few hours, or anyway from the same night.

subsection.name: Radar Observations
subsection.text: Radar astrometry is reported as either the time delay or Doppler frequency shift between transmitter and receiver. It is fundamentally different from optical astrometry not only because of the different observable, but also because the individual data points are one-dimensional and of high fractional precision, potentially at the few meter level in accuracy.

subsection.name: Note 1
Note 2
subsection.text: The MPC1992 astrometry format recorded the date and time of observation in decimal day format. The IAU2015 standard breaks from that historical format to use the ISO 8601 standard date/time format. (See, for example, https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISO\verb|_|8601.) There are a number of advantages to this standard, including wide availability of libraries in many programming languages for input/output of the ISO 8601 time format, reduced ambiguity for times near leap-seconds, and human readability. Additionally, radar astrometry measurements (discussed below) are reported as normal points with a time tag at an integer UT second, and so are not well suited for decimal day representation. A key reason to prefer the decimal day form was that the MPC1992 observations use this format and the precision of the submitted time can be of interest in some cases. To address this need, the time precision of MPC1992 observation records will be preserved in the \texttt{precTime} field, allowing the end-user to reconstruct the decimal day string used in the original MPC1992 submission.

subsection.name: Note 3
subsection.text:
At the workshop there was a lengthy discussion on decimal vs. sexagesimal reporting of angles; however, the clear consensus was to opt for decimal \si{\degree}. The primary reasons for continuing with sexagesimal are a) existing data are already in sexagesimal format and alteration of submitted data is undesirable, and b) the sexagesimal format makes it convenient to plan the sequence of observations during an observing night (by reference to the local apparent sidereal time). The key justification for moving away from sexagesimal representation is that a) it is not suitable for automated data validation of astrometry records using standard computing tools, b) many routine data manipulations and database searches become cumbersome with sexagesimal, for example, selection of observations near a given position (for linkage problems), differencing of sequential positions, routine plotting, etc., c) bugs in the countless different implementations of decimal to sexagesimal conversion tools are persistent and frustrating (e.g., the negative declination bug or "60" appearing in the arcmin or \si{\arcsecond} position), and d) the data exchange standard should mirror the mass data storage format insofar as is practicable, again to avoid alteration of submitted data.
While some operational situations may require sexagesimal values, e.g., for telescope control, ephemeris generation services will continue to provide sexagesimal outputs on request. Typically, targeted observation planning is based on such tabular ephemerides, but in cases where observers refer to astrometric records to sequence observations the conversion to sexagesimal format is straightforward. The IAU2015 standard only specifies a mode of exchange, and users are free to repackage astrometry in whatever form is judged appropriate for local purposes.
The reported precision in archival MPC1992 data records will be preserved in the \texttt{precRA} and \texttt{precDec} fields, which may be useful for correct treatment of the observations and will allow an accurate reconstruction of the original MPC1992 RA and DEC field

section.name: Observation Residuals
Format and Packaging
section.text:
After extensive discussion at the MPC workshop, a consensus was reached that the new standard should support two file formats. XML was selected as the primary vehicle for exchanging data, in large part because of its advantages for computer input/output applications. Among other modern data exchange standards, XML was judged to have the desired maturity and stability (in terms of standards, schema, user base and available libraries) in comparison to some more recent developments that are still evolving, e.g., JSON. XML files are more verbose than those of less flexible formats, but they typically afford excellent compression ratios (e.g., 10:1 and better), substantially mitigating file transmission issues.
However, XML is not suited for plain text viewing and editing, and thus a PSV format (i.e., Pipe Separated Value, similar to CSV) that carries the same information as the XML format will be supported by the standard, although exchange in this format is not encouraged. Rather, we consider it preferable for users to convert PSV files to XML after viewing and editing and before transmission. This has the advantage of automatic data validation and avoids issues with email line wrapping. We anticipate that tools allowing convenient viewing and editing of XML files will be developed by the research community, and that as these tools become available many PSV users will find it more convenient to work directly with XML.
Because of its inherent flexibility, there are no significant packaging challenges with XML. A data file may have only observations, only residuals, or both. Also an XML file may have multiple data types (e.g., radar, ground-based optical, space-based optical, occultation or offset observations) within a file without difficulty. And header information is readily absorbed into the XML file structure, even for multiple batches in a single file. Such flexibility can be preserved in the PSV file format, but not with the same elegance afforded by XML.
The proposed standard will include open source I/O libraries in a number of programming languages, and conversion scripts to and from XML and PSV. This software will allow for robust error checking, file merging/splitting, and other utility functions. For the current version of the standard a requirement of lossless conversion between XML and PSV will be enforced, both for data records and submission headers.

subsection.name: Primary Exchange Format \textemdash XML
subsection.text: The exact formulation of the XML format is under development, but it should be similar to the example given in the figure below, where an \texttt{ObservationChunk} element includes an \texttt{obsContext} sub-element (i.e., the header) and an \texttt{observations} sub-element, which holds the observations. Multiple \texttt{ObservationChunk} blocks may be included in one submission file when, for example, the header information changes within a given submission. In the XML format users are discouraged from adding leading or trailing blanks. Keywords are written in so called lowerCamelCase, i.e., lowercase except that wordbreaks are marked by an uppercase letter. Initialisms and acronyms (e.g., ID, RA, SNR) are not written in mixed case.

subsection.name: Secondary Exchange Format \textemdash PSV
subsection.text:
Despite its advantages, XML is inconvenient for visual inspection of observation files and for manually editing records, which is sometimes required. Therefore the IAU2015 standard accommodates an alternate exchange format, namely a plain text Pipe Separated Values (PSV) file. (An example is depicted at right.) Blanks will normally be used as padding to obtain column alignment of the data fields, but this is not strictly necessary. Since the pipe character `\verb.|.' serves as delimiter it is not an allowed character in the fields defined by this standard. Null fields are empty (i.e., consecutive delimiters: `\verb.||.') or filled with blanks in the blank-padded format.
In the PSV format a submission batch includes a header block and one or more data blocks. Each data block starts with a keyword record that specifies the keywords and their order, followed by a series of data records that follow the structure of the keyword record. Multiple data blocks can follow a single header block, and multiple submission batches can be concatenated into one PSV file. The header information is generally optional, but mandatory for MPC submissions. The keyword record is a mandatory first record for any data block.
The header section loosely follows the structure in the XML example above, but without the use of XML tags. The higher-level "group" keywords are preceded by a `\verb|#|' character and the lower-level "element" keywords are preceded by a `!' character. For example, \begin{verbatim} # observers ! name P. Villa ! name F. Madero # telescope ! aperture 1.5 ! design Reflector ! detector CCD # comment This is a comment. And it # comment can be quite long. \end{verbatim}
New submission batches are distinguished by a new header block, and new data blocks are identified by their keyword records. Each data block can have a different keyword list, as defined by the corresponding keyword record. In this way, for instance, different data types (e.g., optical and radar) can be in the same file without necessarily including all possible fields on each data record.
The first non-blank record following the header block must be a keyword record, a PSV record specifying the keywords and the order that they take in the current batch. \begin{verbatim} KEY1 | KEY2 | KEY3 | ... \end{verbatim} To readily recognize the keyword record when parsing the file we require that the first keyword be \texttt{permID}, even when it has a null value. Thus, the keyword record is by having \texttt{permID} as the first six non-blank characters.
After the keyword record, the observation data records are reported as \begin{verbatim} VALUE1 | VALUE2 | VALUE3 | ... \end{verbatim}
For easier visual inspection and editing, the PSV file can optionally be blank-padded for column alignment. The blank padding can be extended to the keyword record, which will keep the keywords above their data columns, or the blank padding can include only the data records, which will generally lead to a more compact format.
{\em Default PSV:} As a convenience for some users, the standard does define a default PSV template that is compliant with the standard. This template will afford a human readable format that can be widely used for many basic astrometric submission purposes. The table at right lists the field names, their order and the field width for this default format. Any fields present in the record but not listed in the table will be placed in arbitrary order between the \texttt{notes} and \texttt{remarks} fields. (The first three records in the PSV example above use the default PSV form. The last three records in the example show an alternate form of blank padding.) With this format the record length is 156 characters (plus optional fields after the \texttt{notes} and any \texttt{remarks}). Conversion utilities will include the option to produce files with the default template. However, use of the default template is not required: the only requirement for submission is the compliance with the general standards detailed in this document.

subsection.name: Packaging
subsection.text:
After adoption by the IAU and the MPC, IAU2015 will become the MPC's primary means of submission and dissemination and observers are strongly encouraged to adopt the new format as soon as practicable. (The 80-column MPC1992 format will be deprecated but continue to be accepted for an indefinite but limited time period.) The submission of IAU2015 observations to the MPC will be possible in three ways: Web form, cURL, and email (XML only).
The only acceptable format for email submission is anticipated to be XML, either compressed or uncompressed. For the observers who prefer the PSV format, a web interface to upload observation submissions will be provided. The backend engine of the web interface will convert the supplied data file to XML and validate it as a part of the ingestion pipeline at the MPC. The MPC will also disseminate the data in the XML form of the IAU2015 standard, eventually with the option of downloading the observation residual data and submission headers. Users may use local scripts or MPC web forms to convert from XML to PSV and back. Scripts will provide a user option to include or exclude header information when converting from XML to PSV format.
The observational data defined in Sec. 4 must be packaged within a single file. In particular, when satellite or roving observations are exchanged the information on the observer location must be contained in the same file as the observations, rather than in a separate file. On the other hand, the residuals and related fields may be included in the observation file or stored in a separate file. In the case of a single file, the observation residual fields have to be horizontally concatenated to the observational data and the residual header has to be vertically concatenated to the submission header. In the case of two different files, \texttt{obsID} should be reported on each record in the residual file to allow cross-referencing with the observation records.

To support the transition to the new format, software tools will be made publicly available. An ad hoc volunteer software committee was formed at the MPC workshop. Co-chairs are A. Chamberlin and L. Denneau. Additional membership includes P. Chodas, T. Grav, S. Keys and A. Milani. The objective of this committee is to facilitate the development of software and libraries in a number of widely used languages, e.g., Perl, Python, FORTRAN, C++. The software packages will include I/O libraries for extending custom software and scripts for file utilities such as error checking, conversion (between PSV and XML), merging and splitting.
Software packages should append a checksum value to the end of an XML file. If provided, it should be the last line in the file and its value is the MD5 checksum of the file prior to appending the MD5 element onto it. This can be used for submissions by curl to check if there was any corruption in the transmission of the file. Upon receipt, the MPC would compute the MD5 checksum of the file without the line containing the MD5 element and report an error back to the submitter if the values disagreed.
Please note that potential users should not begin to write source code to accommodate the new exchange standard before communicating with the software committee. The standard will eventually include XML schema files and XSLT files for translation from XML to PSV, and the software committee will develop these as standard data products that will be under centralized control to ensure compliance with the standard. Also, numerous finer details remain to be resolved, many of which will not be obvious nor fully resolved until the software implementation is complete.

title.name: Tables of ADES Tags and Structures

XSDTypes.doc:
These types are used to restrict values as appropriate in the various fields. The restrictions are
No '|' characters allowed Strings have length limitations Strings must have particular values decimal types must be in a range

simpletype.name: AlphaNumericType
simpletype.doc: AlphaNumericType restricts the field to only the ASCII upper- and lower-case letters, ASCII numbers and underscores

simpletype.name: BandType
simpletype.doc: MPC maintains a list of bands for magnitude observations

simpletype.name: CatType
simpletype.doc: MPC maintains a list of current astrometry and photometry catalogs

simpletype.name: CorrDecimalType
simpletype.doc: CorrDecimal in range [-1.0, 1.0]

simpletype.name: DeclinationType
simpletype.doc: $\mathrm{DEC}$ in degrees in range [-90.0, 90.0]

simpletype.name: DeprecatedType
simpletype.doc: X marks the use of deprecated data

simpletype.name: DiscType
simpletype.doc: Used to mark the discovery record -- must be `*' or `+' if present

simpletype.name: SubFrmType
simpletype.doc: The submission frame, usually B1950.0 or earlier. If this field is not present, the submission frame was J2000.0

simpletype.name: LeapSecondsHelp
simpletype.doc: Allowed leap seconds before 2017 are valid leap-seconds; for 2017 and later are all allowed June and December leap-second opportunities.

simpletype.name: LogicalType
simpletype.doc: 0 for false, 1 for true to match C and FORTRAN

simpletype.name: ModeType
simpletype.doc: The MPC maintains a list of mode values

simpletype.name: ObsCenterType
simpletype.doc: May be PlanetNameType, PermIDType or ProvIDType

simpletype.name: NotesType
simpletype.doc: up to six single-character notes from MPC table

simpletype.name: ObsIDType
simpletype.doc: An obsID is up to nineteen alphanumeric characters

simpletype.name: PermIDType
simpletype.doc: A permID (permanent ID) string may be a positive integer, a positive integer followed by P or D, a planet name followed by a positive integer, or a positive integer in parentheses followed by a postive integer. These indicate a minor planet, a comet, a natural satellite of a planet, and a natural satellite of a minor planet respectively.

simpletype.name: PhotModType
simpletype.doc: Photometric model is up to eight alphanumeric characters

simpletype.name: PlanetNameType
simpletype.doc: List of planet names, including Earth's Moon

simpletype.name: PosDecimalType
simpletype.doc: PositiveDecimal in range (0.0, +inf)

simpletype.name: ProgType
simpletype.doc: MPC maintains a list of 1 and 2 character program codes

simpletype.name: ProvIDType
simpletype.doc: A provID (provisional ID) is may be a minor planet provid, which is a 4-digit year followed by a space followd by two letters followed optinally by digits; or a comet it, which is C/ or P/ or D/ or X/ or A/ (for asteroids with comet numbers, which may not have fragments) followed by a 4-digit year follwed by a space followed by one or two digits optinally followed by one or two digits optionally followed by "-[A-Z]" (for a commet fragment); or a satellite, which is S/ followed by a 4-digit year followed a space followed either (by a minor planet PermID in parentheses or the bare letter M, J, S, N, U) followed by a space followed by digits.

simpletype.name: RaDecPrecType
simpletype.doc: RaDecPrecType is used to describe the precision of a decimal value when the orignal measurement was made in sexagesimal. The allowed values are applied to the last sexagesimal element, which may be seconds or arcseconds, and mean (for time) the value is accurate to an hour, 10 minutes, 1 minute, 6 seconds, 1 second, .1 second and so forth.

simpletype.name: RAType
simpletype.doc: RA in degrees limited to [0.0, 360.0)

simpletype.name: RefType
simpletype.doc: MPC-assigned reference, up to sixteen characters

simpletype.name: RemarkType
simpletype.doc: A remark is a String limited to 200 characters

simpletype.name: SelResType
simpletype.doc: SelRes must be ``A," (automatic accept) ``a," (manual accept)``D," (automatic delete) or ``d" (manual delete)

simpletype.name: StationType
simpletype.doc: A stn, rov, trx or tcv station. Values vary and are checked by MPC

simpletype.name: StringType
simpletype.doc: String follows the ADES specification in that the pipe character is disallowed in PSV. To allow data conversion from XML, it must disallowed in XML as well. Also disallow blank elements. Therefore, all elements must match this pattern

simpletype.name: SubFmtType
simpletype.doc: MPC maintains a list of allowed submission formats with no extra fields, up to four alphanumeric characters

simpletype.name: SysType
simpletype.doc: Coordinate system for station coordinates. This is used by the pos[123] and poscov[123][123] elements to determine the meaning of coordinates. WGS84, ITRF and IAU are for ground-based stations, ICRF\verb|_|AU and ICRF\verb|_|KM are for space-based stations.

simpletype.name: TimeHelp
simpletype.doc: Restrict dateTime to 4-digit positive years and Z for UTC

simpletype.name: TimePrecType
simpletype.doc: TimePrecType is used to describe the precision of a Time value when the orignal measurement was made in fractional days. The accuracy is in millionths of decimal day, so 10 means 1/100,000 of a day, a little better than a second. The large values are only for historic data on comets.

simpletype.name: TimeType
simpletype.doc: TimeType is an ISO8601 UTC time in the format yyyy-mm-ddThh:mm:ss(.s+)Z. The trailing Z means it is interpreted as UTC. It is not a restriction of xsd:dateTime because that does not properly validate leapseconds. It allows positive 4-digit years and validates the Gregorian calendar for all dates. Note this works because xsd or's all the restrictions and accepts any match. LeapSecondsHelp matches any leapsecond before 2017 and any potential new leapseconds from 2017.

simpletype.name: TrkIDType
simpletype.doc: A trkID is up to twelve alphanumeric characters

simpletype.name: TrkSubType
simpletype.doc: A trkSub is up to eight alphanumeric characters

simpletype.name: VersionType
simpletype.doc: Version attribute for the current ADES schema must be ``2017"

complextype.name: NamesType
complextype.doc: List of one or more names of type String

complextype.name: SubmitterType
complextype.doc: Submitter information. A name field (initials plus surname), an institution string

complextype.name: SoftwareType
complextype.doc: information about software used in processing

complextype.name: CommentType
complextype.doc: List of one or more lines of type String

grouptype.name: MPCID
grouptype.doc: permID or provID or both in that order, or artSat

grouptype.name: OpticalID
grouptype.doc: An MPCID group or trkSub or both in that order. Of permID, provID, artSat or trkSub at least one must be present in an optical observation but all three might be present. Also, MPC will assign unique obsID and trkID fields for distribution

grouptype.name: RadarID
grouptype.doc: An MPCID group only; radar has no equivalent of the optical ``trkSub" field. MPC will add a unique obsID field for distribution

grouptype.name: RadarValue
grouptype.doc: A RadarValue is used for doppler or delay values and errors in a radar observation.

grouptype.name: Precision
grouptype.doc: Precision is primarily for M92 and M47 formats. However, it may be used generally to describe data originally obtained with a certain sexagesimal precision instead of a decimal precision

grouptype.name: Location
grouptype.doc: location data for a rover station.

grouptype.name: Photometry
grouptype.doc: The Photometry group is optional in all optical observation types (optical, offset, and occultation). The "mag" and "band" fields must be present; the rest are optional but can only occur if "mag" and "band" are present to define this as a Photometry group

grouptype.name: OffsetVal
grouptype.doc: OffsetVal allows either rectangular or polar coordinates for the offset measurement. The rectangular coordinates are deltaRA and deltaDec; the polar coordinates are dist and polar angle.

grouptype.name: OpticalRes
grouptype.doc: OpticalRes is optional for the OpticalResiduals group

grouptype.name: OpticalResMag
grouptype.doc: OpticalRes is optional for the OpticalResiduals group

grouptype.name: OpticalResiduals
grouptype.doc: The OpticalResiduals group is optional for adding residuals to optical observations, or as a separate obsResidual element tagged by obsID

grouptype.name: RadarResiduals
grouptype.doc: The RadarResiduals group is optional for adding residuals to optical observations, or as a separate obsResidual element tagged by obsID

complextype.name: LocalUseType
complextype.doc: This element is to allow arbitrary fields for private data interchange

complextype.name: OpticalType
complextype.doc: Optical Observation with RA and Dec

complextype.name: OffsetType
complextype.doc: Optical Offset Observation with RA and Dec

complextype.name: OccultationType
complextype.doc: Optical Occultation Observation with deltaRA, deltaDec, raStar and decStar

complextype.name: RadarType
complextype.doc: Radar Observation using either doppler or delay values from RadarValue

complextype.name: ObsDataType
complextype.doc: A list of all optical or all radar observations

complextype.name: ObsBlockType
complextype.doc: A list of all optical or all radar observations, with context

complextype.name: OpticalResType
complextype.doc: Optical Residual outside of the optical/occulatation/offset structure

complextype.name: RadarResType
complextype.doc: Radar Residual outside of the radar structure

complextype.name: ADESType
complextype.doc: This is what is allowed in ades documents -- any of these in any order

XSDElementTypes.doc: These elements are for the observation types in the required order

element.name: permID
element.doc: IAU permanent designation, i.e., IAU number

element.name: provID
element.doc: MPC provisional designation (unpacked form) for unnumbered object

element.name: trkSub
element.doc: Observer-assigned tracklet identifier, unique within submission batch.

element.name: obsID
element.doc: Globally Unique Observation ID assigned by MPC

element.name: trkID
element.doc: Globally Unique alphnumeric tracklet ID assigned by MPC

element.name: mode
element.doc: Mode of optical and offset observations.

element.name: sys
element.doc: Coordinate system for station coordinates and covariance.

element.name: ctr
element.doc: Origin of the reference system. Use public SPICE codes, e.g., 399 is the geocenter, 10 is the Sun center. Note; sys=WGS84 implies ctr=399

element.name: prog
element.doc: Program code as assigned by the MPC.

element.name: obsTime
element.doc: UTC time of the observation in ISO 8601 format, i.e., {\em yyyy-mm-ddThh:mm:ss.ssZ}.

element.name: ra
element.doc: J2000.0 Astrometric equatorial right ascension in decimal degrees.

element.name: dec
element.doc: J2000.0 Astrometric equatorial declination in decimal degrees. Positive DEC values may optionally include a \verb|+| sign

element.name: raStar
element.doc: J2000.0 RA in decimal degrees of the occulted star

element.name: decStar
element.doc: J2000.0 DEC in decimal degrees of the occulted star

element.name: obsCenter
element.doc: Center of offset observation may be planet or other body with PermID or ProvID

element.name: deltaRA
element.doc: Measured $\Delta(\mathrm{RA}\cos\mathrm{ DEC})$ in arcseconds. For offset measurements of a satellite with respect to its primary, or for occultation observations with respect to the star in rectangular coordinates, J2000.0 frame.

element.name: deltaDec
element.doc: Measured $\Delta$DEC in arcseconds. For offset measurements of a satellite with respect to its primary, or for occultation observations with respect to the star in rectangular coordinates, J2000.0 frame

element.name: dist
element.doc: Measured distance in arcseconds. For offset measurements of a satellite with respect to its primary, or for occultation observations with respect to the star in polar coordinates.

element.name: pa
element.doc: Measured position angle in degrees. For offset measurements of a satellite with respect to its primary, or for occultation observations with respect to the star in polar coordinates.

element.name: rmsRA
element.doc: Random component of the $\mathrm{RA}\cos\mathrm{DEC}$ $1\sigma$ uncertainty in arcseconds as estimated by the observer as part of the image processing and astrometric reduction.

element.name: rmsDec
element.doc: Random component of the DEC $1\sigma$ uncertainty in arcseconds as estimated by the observer as part of the image processing and astrometric reduction.

element.name: rmsDist
element.doc: Random component of the distance $1\sigma$ uncertainty in arcseconds as estimated by the observer as part of the image processing and astrometric reduction.

element.name: rmsPA
element.doc: Random component of the polar angle $1\sigma$ uncertainty in degrees as estimated by the observer as part of the image processing and astrometric reduction.

element.name: rmsCorr
element.doc: Correlation between RA and DEC or dist and PA that may result from the astrometric reduction. This is derived from the $\mathrm{RA}$-$\mathrm{DEC}$ or $\mathrm{dist}$-$\mathrm{PA}$ covariance matrix, where the off-diagonal term is $\mathrm{rmsCorr} * \mathrm{rmsRA} * \mathrm{rmsDec}$ or $\mathrm{rmsCorr} * \mathrm{rmsDist} * \mathrm{rmsPA}$.

element.name: delay
element.doc: Observed radar delay value in seconds.

element.name: rmsDelay
element.doc: Measurement $1\sigma$ uncertainty in \si{\micro\second} for radar delay

element.name: rmsDoppler
element.doc: Measurement $1\sigma$ uncertainty in \si{\hertz} for radar doppler

element.name: astCat
element.doc: Star catalog used for the astrometric reduction or for the occulted star in the case of occultation observations.)

element.name: photCat
element.doc: Star catalog used for photometry measurements.

element.name: nucMag
element.doc: Nuclear magnitude flag for comets. 0 for total magnitude (i.e., for most archival comet observations and all asteroid observations), 1 for nuclear magnitude. Primarily used for archival data as photAp should be used to communicate this information in the new standard

element.name: logSNR
element.doc: $\log_{10}$ of the signal-to-noise ratio of the source in the image integrated on the entire aperture used for the astrometric centroid.

element.name: seeing
element.doc: Size of seeing disc in arcseconds, measured at Full Width Half Maximum (FWHM) of target point spread function (PSF).

element.name: exp
element.doc: Exposure time in \si{\second}. Total exposure time in the case of stacked image detections

element.name: rmsFit
element.doc: RMS of fit of astrometric comparison stars in arcseconds.

element.name: nStars
element.doc: Number of stars in astrometric fit.

element.name: com
element.doc: Flag to indicate that the observation is reduced to the center of mass. 0 implies a measurement to the peak power position, which is usually interpreted as the leading edge of the target, with the reflection point being modeled one object radius prior to the center of mass.

element.name: ref
element.doc: Standard reference field used for citations.

element.name: disc
element.doc: Discovery flag; `*' marks a new discovery record; '+' marks the first measurement of a previously observed object; otherwise not present

element.name: subFmt
element.doc: Format in which the observation was originally submitted to the MPC, e.g., M92 for MPC1992 format or A17 for the current standard standard. Filled by the MPC according to a list provided and maintained by the MPC.

element.name: subFrm
element.doc: Reference frame for the original submission of reported angular measurements.

element.name: precTime
element.doc: Precision in millionths of a day of the reported obeservation time for archived MPC1992 data records

element.name: precRA
element.doc: Precision in seconds of the reported RA for archived MPC1992 data records.

element.name: precDec
element.doc: Precision in arcseconds of the reported DEC for archived MPC1992 data records.

element.name: uncTime
element.doc: Estimated time uncertainty in seconds. Unlike the preceding RMS fields, which indicate random errors, this field indicates a presumed level of systematic clock error. NB: This field is generally only to be used to communicate exceptions and problems with clock calibration and is not intended to be used in routine submissions where clock errors are not a significant source of astrometric error.

element.name: notes
element.doc: A set of one-character note flags to communicate observing circumstances.

element.name: remarks
element.doc: Comment field provided by the observer. This field can be used to report additional information that is not reportable in the notes field, but that may be of relevance for interpretation of the observations.

element.name: orbProd
element.doc: Orbit producer. Can be institution, individual, or even email address, e.g.`MPC'

element.name: orbID
element.doc: Local reference for orbit, e.g., `JPL 7' or `MPO 12345'.

element.name: photProd
element.doc: Producer of photometric residuals. Can be institution, individual, or even email address, e.g.`MPC'

element.name: resDelay
element.doc: Residual of the radar measurement in \si{\micro\second} for delay

element.name: sigDelay
element.doc: Adopted uncertainty for the radar measurement in \si{\micro\second} for delay

element.name: resDoppler
element.doc: Residual of the radar measurement in \si{\hertz} for Doppler

element.name: sigDoppler
element.doc: Adopted uncertainty for the radar measurement in \si{\hertz} for Doppler

XSDElementTypes.doc: These elements are for the observation context types

element.name: observers
element.doc: list of observer names (initials then surname)

element.name: measurers
element.doc: list of measurer names (initials then surnames)

element.name: coinvestigators
element.doc: list of coinvestigator names (initials then surname)

element.name: collaborators
element.doc: list of collaborator names (initials then surname)

XSDElementTypes.doc: These are the five observation types

element.name: obsData
element.doc: list of optical or radar observations

element.name: obsBlock
element.doc: obsBlock contains an obsContext and obsData

XSDElementTypes.doc: These are the top-level types for residuals>
